mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Development of a Computer-Vision Based Model to Identify Demolition Activities

mods:name.mods:namePart: Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering

mods:mods.mods:abstract: Demolition projects are dependent on heavy equipment operations, and therefore, the success of these projects hinges on efficient heavy equipment usage. While previous studies have focused on tracking heavy equipment productivity in construction operations, such as earthwork, manually tracking the duration of heavy equipment activities can be time-consuming, labor-intensive, and prone to errors. To address this, recent studies have employed artificial intelligence-based methods to automatically identify heavy equipment activities and measure productivity in construction operations. However, unlike earthwork activities, which are relatively simple and repetitive, demolition activities are more complex and dynamic, involving structural demolition and material separation. As a result, applying existing approaches to identify demolition activities raises questions. This study proposes an automatic vision-based activity identification model that uses three-dimensional Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) to extract spatial and temporal features simultaneously. The model can recognize three excavator activities related to material separation, namely grabbing, swinging, and dumping, used in demolition operations. To develop the model, small-scale excavators were used to simulate real-world demolition operations while recording videos of the experiments using two cameras. The recorded video datasets were manually labeled and used to train the proposed model. Since demolition projects are not as common as construction projects, it can take a while to collect real-world data for training and validating the activity identification model. Thus, small-scale demolition simulations were used to validate the feasibility of the vision-based activity identification model, supporting its application for full-scale demolition productivity improvement. The model achieves an accuracy of 93.68% on the training dataset and 91.84% on the validation dataset. The study highlights the impact of camera placement on the model's performance, suggesting future research to optimize camera placement and configuration. Overall, this research contributes to the development of accurate and effective automated activity identification models for demolition projects. By using computer vision-based models to identify demolition activities automatically, the proposed approach is less labor-intensive, more efficient, and more accurate than traditional approaches, ultimately enhancing the productivity of demolition projects.
mods:mods.mods:note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Civil Engineering.
Activity Identification, Computer Vision, Demolition Projects
Juyeong Choi, Professor Directing Thesis; Yassir AbdelRazig, Committee Member; John Sobanjo, Committee Member; Shayok Chakraborty, Committee Member.
